description.narrative:
Insatsen bedöms viktig för att främja inklusiv tillväxt i Etiopien, på grund av de flerdimensionella hinder som uppstår i ekonomin till följd av låg och ineffektivt fördelad kapitaltillgång för privat näringsverksamhet i landet. I flertalet studier av tillväxt och fattigdom i Etiopien utmärker sig tillgång till finansiering som ett huvudsakligt hinder för hållbar, dynamisk och inklusiv tillväxt. Detta är fallet i synnerhet för små och medelstora företag (SME), som är mest utmärkande och irrationellt förfördelade vad gäller tillgången till kapital i förhållande till deras potential att växa och skapa arbetstillfällen och förbättrade inkomster för biståndets målgrupper. SME-företagen bedöms vara särskilt viktiga för landsbygdens kvinnor, som idag för sin försörjning ofta är beroende av improduktiv självhushållning eller mikroföretag med begränsad potential för tillväxt, expansion och ökade inkomster.
I den kontexten är en holistisk ansats till finansiering önskvärd, en ansats som i flera avseenden adresseras av IFC (International Finance Corporatiopn) i deras nyskapade finansieringsprogram Ethiopia PSD Initiative Access to Finance (A2F). Trots att IFC:s erfarenheter i Etiopien bara sträcker sig tillbaka till 2008, så har institutionen på dessa år ackumulerat värdefulla insikter och nätverk medan dess globala erfarenheter och resurser för privatsektorutveckling i fattiga länder är mycket omfattande och användbara även i den lokala miljön. Detta skapar förutsättningar för IFC att komma igång relativt snabbt med relevanta operationer inom ett genuint ramverk för styrning och kontroll. En ägarskapsfrämjande efterfrågeledd ansats till bistånd tillämpas samtidigt, där programmets olika delar skapas på direkta önskemål från privat och offentlig sektor.

This programme addresses Access to Finance as a critical bottleneck to pro poor growth in Ethiopia. Via engagements for capital markets development, improved SME banking options, leasing practices, corporate governance practices and credit reporting infrastructure, the programme sets out to create 8 0000 new jobs, lift 30 000 people above the 1.25$/day and improve incomes for the 40% of the population

The Ethiopia Private Sector Development Multi-Donor Initiative (MDI) is a joint funding platform that aims to promote private sector development in Ethiopia. The MDI has two pillars: Pillar I Investment Climate (IC), which seeks to improve the investment climate; and Pillar II Access to Finance (A2F), which aims to enhance access to finance for, and promote investments targeting, SMEs. Current donors to the MDI are Canada, Italy, the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, the United Kingdom, and the United States.
Since Sweden has two contributions to two different programs (ICII and A2F), this Conclusion of Performance addresses Access to finance.
COVID-19 Statement: IFC has continued to review and assess the impact of the pandemic on its advisory portfolio and teams continue to adapt work programs where needed. Overall, most projects are proceeding with implementation, albeit with some modifications and extensions in some cases. IFC continues to adapt and respond to the situation through adjusting delivery modes where possible, including implementing innovative approaches. Monitoring the pandemics impact on advisory program delivery remains an ongoing effort and IFC will continue to keep development partners updated. The donors initiated a series of updating meetings first half of 2020 in order to keep up with the impact, and have a dialogue with IFC that they needed to adjust their programming to the current circumstances. As a result less international consultants were hired, more local consultants were hired, and less travel.
Access to Finance (A2F)
The A2F Pillar initially started in 2015, with support initially provided by Sweden, and now includes multiple donors (Canada, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, United Kingdom and United States). A2F includes nine distinct projects in seven areas:
1. Ethiopia Agribusiness
o Ethiopia Grains Agri-Business Development
o Ethiopia Heineken
o Luna Livestock and Outgrower Development
2. Ethiopia Credit Reporting
o Ethiopia Credit Reporting (Project 2)
3. Ethiopia Secured Transactions Collateral Registry
o Ethiopia Secured Transactions Collateral Registry
4. Ethiopia Leasing
o Ethiopia Leasing
5. Ethiopia SME Banking
o Ethiopia SME Banking (Enat Bank)
6. Ethiopia Commodity Collateralized Finance
o Ethiopia MDI Commodity Collateralized Finance
7. Ethiopia Corporate Governance
o Ethiopia Corporate Governance

description.narrative:
Results: the IFC met or exceeded intended results with the following exceptions:
The number of farmers reached (direct and indirect) (only 1,200) compared to the target (7,000) (Luna). Number of inquiries received by credit reporting service provider were only 415,630 compared to a target of 453,959 (Credit Reporting).
Gender Inclusion. There continues to not be a great deal of thought given to gender mainstreaming approaches. For the Trade Facilitation project, there is planned training for women customs agents. The only hesitancy here is that there are no reflection on other jobs lost to automation, and the claim that gender-based violence is reduced by eSW without evidence or measurement, and no reflective work done around the lack of evidence that women appear to be more compliant based on general theory (without citations). In other projects, there is repeated reference to MSMEs and other landscape studies with a focus on gender. There is gender awareness around gender diversity for the Corporate Governance project. At the end-of-project, this is late to be engaging with women. Best practice standards focus on systematic inclusion of gender during project planning rather than ex post facto and ad hoc.
Lessons Learned. The lessons learned are divided into previous ones and new ones. For lessons learned, the big question is if IFC could have discovered this weakness at appraisal, better mitigated the risk, and/or intervened more effectively when the problem was detected? It is unfortunate to still see lessons such as translate into local languages [p. 21] or that policy reforms may take 4-5 years [p. 48] or that it is important to be flexible [p. 59]. The IFC would do well to develop a learning agenda based on evidence to ensure that the learning is more focused and data-driven.
Access to Finance: Projects with Positive Results Likely Leading to Measurable Impact
Credit Reporting (Project 2) *Closed). The Credit Reporting project includes 18 banks and more than 35 microfinance institutions and supports more than 3.5 million borrowers. This meets the project goal of credit coverage of more than 5.0 percent of the adult population. High number of women borrowers (1,837,937) receiving $2,932,886,687 (average amount of $1,596 per borrower).
Projects with Challenges and/or Weak Results
Four projects have either encountered challenges and/or have weak results.
Corporate Governance (CG) (Closed). CG project has primarily provided training and advisories to firms. Results include 5 strategic partners, 30 events for 1,000 individuals trained and an SME Governance Guidebook. IFC has found that firm-level CG work is very challenging in Ethiopia because companies are unable to pay for IFCs advisory services in U.S. dollars. IFC has continuously engaged with NBE, but E&S clauses have yet to be included in the regulatory CG framework [from proposal; p. 35].
Secured Transactions Collateral Registry. The secured transactions collateral registry has achieved major policy and legal reforms (3 moveable property directives (2019-2020); Commercial Code ratified (3/21)), and 42 financial institutions are participating. Next steps will focus on full functionality. Yet, to date, in terms of impact, the secured transactions Collateral Registry has underperformed. While there is six months left in the project, the ability to support endline target beneficiaries is low. Only 568 SMEs (4% of target of 13,340) total received a loan based on movable property. Micro-enterprises (MEs) did better possibly due to the engagement of micro-finance institutions in the project. To date, 507 micro-enterprises (79% of the target of 645) received financing. Overall, the value of financing provided to SMEs is very low. The total provided to SMEs is only 5% of the target of $2,438,452,312. The amount of financing provided to women-owned SMEs is also quite low only 0.4% of the target of $487,690,458.
Luna. Many project components delayed; project not on track due to protracted land tenure process. Luna has moved three times (from Oromia to Tigray to SNCC) and is also seriously delayed; COVID provided further delays; need to conduct a new baseline study. While Lunas ISO 45001:2018 certification is expected end of 2021, other indicators underperform. The export was only (6 or 670 (both mentioned)) metric tons to UAE and Saudi Arabia compared to target of 2,400; 1200 farmers (26% women) coached (compared to target of 7,000); 693 farmers adopted new practices (compared to target of 7,000)
MDI Commodity Collateralized Finance. Policy and legal reforms were achieved (national standards for agricultural warehouses approved (6/19); MoTI issued warehouse receipt directive (9/21) and regulation under review by prime minister). The ECX launched warehouse receipt services and 5 banks have ECX agreements. CCF underperformed on impact only 2 compared to a target of 10 business entities have been granted credit secured with inventory collateral [p. 70]
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
